description: Skills for outdoor ecology education — from species identification to ecosystem analysis and habitat restoration planning. Designed for park naturalist programs, nature camps, and field-based environmental education.

setting_constraints.environment: outdoor — trails, creeks, meadows, forest edges
setting_constraints.connectivity: none — assume no internet or electricity in the field
setting_constraints.materials: physical — field guides, hand lenses, collection jars, pH test strips, compasses, field notebooks
setting_constraints.weather_dependency: high — rain/cold alters available activities; always have indoor fallback
setting_constraints.safety: buddy system required, first aid kit, awareness of poison ivy/ticks/wildlife

skills.label: Can identify 5+ local tree species by leaf shape, bark texture, and silhouette
Can identify 5+ local wildflower species by petal count, color, and leaf arrangement
Can use a dichotomous key or field guide to identify an unfamiliar plant or animal
Can read a topographic map — contour lines, elevation, scale, and cardinal directions
Can orient a compass, take a bearing, and navigate to a waypoint
Can identify animal tracks, scat, nests, burrows, and feeding marks for 5+ local species
Can follow a track line, estimate animal size and gait, and determine direction of travel
Can identify 5+ bird species by sight/sound and describe foraging, nesting, or territorial behavior
Can test water pH, turbidity, dissolved oxygen, and temperature using a field kit
Can collect and identify common aquatic macroinvertebrates as water quality indicators
Can record structured field observations: date, location, weather, species list, sketches, and questions
Can create labeled field sketches of plants, insects, or landscape features with accurate proportions
Can identify and describe distinct microhabitats within a larger ecosystem (rotting log, stream edge, canopy gap)
Can construct and explain a local food web connecting producers, consumers, and decomposers observed in the field
Can evaluate habitat health using multiple indicators: species diversity, water quality, canopy cover, invasive species presence
Can explain how seasonal cycles affect species behavior, plant phenology, and ecosystem dynamics
Can compare two different local ecosystems and explain why they support different species communities
Can plan and lead a 30-minute interpretive nature walk for peers, pointing out species and ecological relationships
Can design a habitat restoration plan: identify degradation causes, select native species for replanting, create a monitoring schedule
